Topic: Mechanism Design
When markets fail (e.g., in the presence of public goods, externalities, and asymmetric information), or do not exist (e.g., in allocating kidneys to patients, or students to schools), can we design decentralized mechanisms to bring about desirable allocations? Mechanism design (aka market design) provides some answers. Some designed mechanisms are market-like, e.g., SO2 emissions markets or electric power exchanges; others involve auctions, such as spectrum auctions in mobile telephony; yet others involve matching such as the allocation of physicians to residency programs, or ventilators to patients. We will study the general theory of economic design, the manipulability of mechanisms, including auctions and matching mechanisms.
